Award.AwardTitle: Doctoral Dissertation Improvement Grant: Developing Approaches to Food Analysis

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Division.LongName: Division Of Behavioral and Cognitive Sci

Award.AbstractNarration:
Food is foundational to everything from daily life and the economy to social connections and religious practices. Archaeological finds of ancient pottery offer an abundant source of material evidence for the ways people stored, prepared, cooked, and ate food from prehistory to today. Traces of food preserved in the pores of pottery provide direct evidence for how people used their pots in the past; combined with radiocarbon dating of individual molecules from these food residues, they are a powerful tool for reconstructing the practices that shaped the food systems which form the foundation of today’s global food system. Past scholarship has paid little attention to how the diversity of environments and food sources worldwide might complicate interpretations of what a pot once held. This project will develop a robust approach to interpreting the sources of food residues in pottery that is sensitive to differences in the environment. Through collaborations with researchers in food science, engineering, chemistry, and soil sciences, this research offers contributions to fields such as food science, sustainability, and renewable energy, and unique training opportunities for student research assistants.

The research team will study the complications caused by regional differences in climate and the environment: different conditions can create more than one possible interpretation of the food sources that could have caused the particular collection of molecules observed by an archaeologist in a pot fragment. This problem arises because many foods are made up of similar molecules, or can look similar because of environmental processes at archaeological sites that break down food over time. The researchers will develop methods to combat this problem, focusing on the Mediterranean, a region with a distinctive climate and a uniquely rich archaeological and historical record where key regional food systems developed. By developing a novel laboratory-based experiment that can incorporate different soils in a simulation of the breakdown of different food products over time, the researchers will provide an efficient, region-specific experimental design applicable worldwide, not only for archaeology but for any field (such as food science or sustainability) that requires the study of how food breaks down in soils. Drawing on supercritical fluid extraction, a technique used in renewable energies research, the team will also produce an optimized method for recovering food residues that minimizes the loss of interpretative information about a pot’s contents. The researchers will also evaluate whether environmental differences pose a challenge to using radiocarbon dating of individual food molecules to link the archaeology of everyday life to a historical timeline. By applying these developments to three case-studies the researchers will produce robust datasets that advance the understanding of past food practices and their entanglement in politics, religion, and the economy.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Olive oil and other plant oils were important food, personal hygiene, and lighting sources in the ancient Mediterranean. Yet our ability to study the early history of plant oils is hampered by the fact that they are not usually preserved on archaeological sites. Archaeologists have therefore turned to the study of traces of foods preserved in the pores of ancient pottery using methods drawn from organic chemistry and biogeochemistry (organic residue analysis) to identify the past contents of pottery and how pots were used. Our project investigated a key factor that impacts how effective these organic residue analysis methods are in recovering and identifying plant oil – namely, the chemistry of the soil that ancient pottery is buried in. Previous research had suggested that the preservation of organic residues was likely to be worse in the Mediterranean compared to other regions of the world, but until our project, this hypothesis had not yet been tested experimentally. We ran a year-long experiment drawing on chemical engineering, food science, and soil science knowledge that modeled the breakdown of olive oil residues in replica pottery buried in two different soils – a soil from Cyprus and a soil from New York State. The experiment showed that, as expected, the preservation of plant oil residues was worse in pottery buried in the Mediterranean soil than in the New York soil, and that plant oils would therefore be more difficult to identify from trace residues in ancient pottery on a site with lime-rich soil. We corroborated these results by recovering organic residues from ancient storage jars found in large-scale storage facilities at two early urban sites in Late Bronze Age Cyprus (1600-1150 BCE), one of which was from the same type of the soil as the Cypriot soil used for the experiment. While some of the storage jars contained evidence for plant products, including possibly plant oils, the preservation of organic residues was as poor, as predicted by our experiment. 

Our findings call into question previous theories about how the economy of early cities in Cyprus was organized, in particular how the rising class of elites at these cities managed their food and other agricultural resources. Previous research had held the large-scale storage facilities that appeared in the first cities on Cyprus in the Late Bronze Age were used by elites as dedicated facilities for a vast olive oil industry. However, our new data with up-to-date methods showed the idea of a large-scale olive oil industry should be reconsidered and other uses for the large-scale storage facilities should be considered. Our results also show that archaeologists and scientists need to rethink what methods and evidence will be most effective in tracing the early history of olive oil and other important oils, which will allow us to gain a better understanding of the ancient Mediterranean economy as well as how the development of different agricultural industries such as plant oil production reshaped human daily life.

This project integrated methods from several disciplines across STEM, the social sciences, and humanities, including chemistry, chemical and environmental engineering, soil science, food science, anthropology, Classics, and archaeology, building collaborations across Cornell University that have led to a broader interest and investment in the intersection of archaeology and chemical approaches at Cornell. The project also contributed to training of four STEM scholars (the Co-PI and three undergraduate research assistants) from backgrounds underrepresented in STEM.
